I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help the Ministry of Environment 
and Tourism (MET) of Mongolia improve the management of hazardous chemicals by establishing 
a comprehensive and dynamic web-based management information system (MIS) and building 
the capacity of national agencies to use the system.1 
 
2.  The TA supports the country partnership strategy for Mongolia, 2017–2020 of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and is listed in the country operations business plan, 2019–2021. It 
supports ADB’s Strategy 2030’s operational priorities on environmental sustainability, livable cities, 
and strengthening governance and institutional capacity.2 The TA is aligned with Mongolia’s National 
Program for Reducing Air and Environmental Pollution, 2017–2025, which prioritizes environmental 
pollution control.3 Addressing the management of hazardous chemicals also contributes to the 
Sustainable Development Goals 3 (good health and well-being), 6 (clean water and sanitation), 11 
(sustainable cities and communities), and 12 (responsible consumption and production).4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Chemicals  are  critical  to  manufacturing  pharmaceutical,  agricultural,  and  industrial 
products and help protect human health. However, the use and byproducts of many chemicals, 
and their discharge through air and water emissions and combustion processes, pose risks to 
human health and the environment. For many countries, including Mongolia, there is limited 
knowledge about the types and volumes of chemicals in use, especially hazardous chemicals. 
Addressing this issue is a global priority for chemicals management.5 
 
4.  Most chemicals in Mongolia are imported due to limited capacity for domestic production. 
Until 1990, chemicals were imported from the former Soviet Union. Since Mongolia’s transition to 
a market economy, key sources of chemical imports have expanded to include the People’s 
Republic of China, the Republic of Korea, and the United States. About 260 agencies in Mongolia 
are currently registered to import chemicals and, since 2014, around 430,000 tons of 2,600 types 
of chemicals are estimated to have been imported, largely for commercial use.6 These include 
hazardous chemicals, such as mercury, cyanide, petroleum and crude oil (used in the mining 
industry), bleaching and brighteners (for tanneries), battery acids (for vehicles), and coolants (for 
refrigeration). Monitoring and reporting are a key step toward managing hazardous chemicals in 
Mongolia but are hindered by two key issues. 
 
5.  First, no centralized MIS for hazardous chemicals exists. A range of national agencies 
record data on the import and use of hazardous chemicals, but data collection is not harmonized or 
consistent. This limits the ability of the MET and other agencies to effectively monitor the import,

2 
use, and disposal of hazardous chemicals and hinders interagency information exchange. This 
increases the risk of unauthorized chemical imports that exceed approved quotas.7 Mongolia’s Law 
on Hazardous and Toxic Chemicals identifies the need for a national MIS for hazardous chemicals 
and mandates the MET to lead the monitoring of hazardous chemicals. To be effective, the design 
of such an MIS needs to be a web-based, dynamic system that is user-friendly, can be accessed 
by  key  agencies,  and  is  aligned  with  international  databases  for  monitoring  of  hazardous 
substances. The MET lacks the technological and financial resources to develop this database, 
which requires specialized skills in computer programming combined with chemicals expertise. 
 
6.  Second, government agencies responsible for monitoring hazardous chemicals have 
limited capacity to identify, inspect, and manage chemicals. Other national agencies help the MET 
monitor chemicals: the Mongolian Customs General Administration (inspecting goods at border 
crossings),  General  Agency  for  Supervision  and  Inspection  (company  compliance  with 
regulations  for  the  safe  transport,  use,  and  disposal  of  chemicals),  National  Agency  for 
Meteorology and Environmental Monitoring (testing and analysis of chemical products), and the 
National Emergency Management Agency (safety codes and procedures for chemical spills). 
These agencies lack simple, portable equipment to help field personnel conduct on-the-spot 
diagnoses for chemical products (e.g., at border crossings, work places, and disposal sites), 
access reference information, and/or enter standardized data to a centralized database. 
 
7.  Supported by development partners and donors, especially organizations and programs 
of the United Nations and Global Environment Facility, the government has initiated steps to 
address these issues. Under the National Council on Toxic and Hazardous Substances Affairs, a 
regulatory framework of laws, policies, and programs to manage hazardous chemicals has been 
established. Mongolia adopted the Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling 
of Chemicals in 2009 and enacted a hazardous waste classification system in 2015.8 Mongolia is 
also a signatory to international treaties and conventions for hazardous chemicals, and is a focal 
country for international efforts to address the unregulated use of chemicals such as mercury.9 
Reviews of national priorities for managing chemicals in Mongolia consistently emphasize the 
need for an MIS on hazardous chemicals.10 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: environmental pollution from hazardous 
chemicals reduced and safer living environment ensured (footnote 3). The TA will have the 
following outcome: monitoring of hazardous chemicals in Mongolia improved.11 
                                                
7  D. Naransukh and A. Frank. 2018. Asbestos Consumption in Mongolia: 1996–2014. International Journal of 
Environmental Research and Public Health. 15 (1). p. 136. 
8  United Nations. 2011. Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals. New York; 
Government of Mongolia. 2015. Hazardous Waste Classifications System. Resolution No. 263. Ulaanbaatar. 
9  Mongolia is a signatory to the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes

United Nations and other partners are assisting the government to prepare and/or implement national implementation

3 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Web-based MIS for hazardous chemicals established. This output will 
design and establish a national MIS to record and monitor the use of hazardous chemicals. The 
MET  will  be  responsible  for  the  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  of  the  MIS.  Other 
stakeholders—including  government  agencies  for  monitoring,  enforcement,  and  research; 
companies registered to import and/or use hazardous chemicals; and the general public—will 
have regulated access to the MIS. The MIS will include an interactive system for data entry, 
storage, use, and retrieval; recording of spatial data (e.g., locations of border crossings, transport 
routes, and work sites where hazardous chemicals are used); automated “red-flag” warnings for 
specific chemicals, volumes, and/or protocols (e.g., to alert border officials on the sensitivity of a 
shipment under inspection); user-friendly functions, forms, and web pages in Mongolian and 
English, including drop-down menus to standardize data entry; automated queries and generation 
of summary statistics and reports; information and maps for public viewing; and a mobile 
application for users to access the MIS in the field. Data will include an inventory of known 
chemicals used in Mongolia; import quotas and documented import volumes for hazardous 
chemicals; chemical licensing details for companies, including permitted import volumes and 
conditions for use; and real-time monitoring data, entered by officials (e.g., at border crossings 
and during site inspections), company personnel (to comply with license conditions), and the 
general public (e.g., to report disposal of hazardous material).12 
 
10.  The MIS will enable the MET to quickly generate and review information (e.g., to compare 
actual import volumes for a company against permitted volumes); provide timely information to 
the National Council on Toxic and Hazardous Substances Affairs (e.g., to establish new quotas 
or bans on specific chemicals); improve data exchange with other stakeholders; and increase the 
transparency of information provided to the general public. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Capacity  for  the  monitoring  of  hazardous  chemicals  improved.  The 
effectiveness of output 1 will depend on the provision of hardware necessary to operate the MIS; 
adequate technical capacity of staff tasked with O&M, data entry, and use of the MIS; and 
continued O&M of the MIS after the project. Output 2 will (i) identify and procure the hardware 
required to operate the MIS;13 (ii) identify the staff positions in the MET and other national 
agencies that will operate, maintain, and use the MIS, and prepare work tasks for the terms of 
reference of these positions; (iii) prepare an O&M manual for the MIS and hardware, including 
roles and responsibilities of agencies and staff positions, procedures for O&M and data entry and 
use, and costs and funding sources for O&M of the MIS and hardware; (iv) conduct a capacity 
assessment  and  training  program  for  key  agencies  and  personnel  involved  in  chemicals 
management, including procedures for O&M of the MIS and on-site reporting of hazardous 
chemicals; and (v) identify additional equipment beyond the scope of the TA that national 
agencies may require to improve the monitoring and reporting of hazardous chemicals, including 
estimated costs for purchase and operation, and potential funding sources. 
 
12.  Promoting innovation, knowledge, and value added by ADB assistance. The TA will 
establish  Mongolia’s first MIS  and mobile application  for monitoring hazardous chemicals: a 
powerful and innovative tool to help manage environmental pollution and support Mongolia’s 
reporting responsibilities under international treaties. The TA complements the efforts of other 
                                                
12 Data entry, including an inventory of chemicals used in Mongolia, will begin during TA implementation and be led 
initially by the TA firm responsible for the design and piloting of the MIS, and a TA-funded information technology 
specialist (section D). Handover of data entry tasks to the agencies that will be responsible for O&M of the MIS will 
begin during TA implementation. Data will be sourced from digital and hard copy records. 
13 Anticipated to include servers, external hard drives, global positioning systems, and handheld tablets.

4 
development partners and donors that are supporting chemicals management in Mongolia (footnote 
9), but which do not include the development of an MIS; and will be implemented in close 
collaboration with other agencies to ensure alignment with other existing national databases. The 
TA modality is appropriate for delivering the MIS and reflects the added value of ADB support by 
facilitating a tailored approach which integrates technology, chemicals knowledge, and capacity 
building. The TA will apply best practice principles and standards for chemicals management and 
ensure that the MIS is aligned with global databases such as the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations–Japan Chemical Safety Database.14 The TA will assess the potential to apply high-level 
technology concepts such as artificial intelligence for MIS design and disseminate lessons learned 
from the TA through at least three workshops and a technical report. The TA also builds on a 
growing platform of government requested ADB support to strengthen the use of information 
technology and digital resources in Mongolia, including improved customs automation at border 
crossings and two national databases under development for social services and state registries.15 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $770,000, of which $750,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Japan Fund for Information and Communication Technology and administered by ADB. The 
key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The following are ineligible expenditures: (i) purchase 
of vehicles, (ii) salaries for civil servants, (iii) foreign travel, (iv) scholarships or long internships, (v) 
detailed engineering designs, (vi) civil works and other related expenses, and (vii) activities under 
ADB’s List of Ineligible Items (or Negative List) and Prohibited Investment Activities List.16  
 
14.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of a steering committee to 
coordinate TA project implementation, counterpart staff, internal coordination, and other in-kind 
contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA and select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. The MET, 
acting through the Department of Green Development Policy and Strategic Planning, will be the 
executing agency for the TA. The department is implementing other ADB-funded projects and has 
adequate capacity to facilitate the TA implementation. Other agencies, development partners, 
and donors involved in the monitoring and/or use of hazardous chemicals in Mongolia will be 
invited to participate in the TA workshops, meetings, and trainings.

and Communication Technology and will comply with the trust fund guidelines. 
 
20.  Sustainability.  The TA  is  designed to maximize  sustainability  of  the  MIS  after TA 
completion. The TA consulting services will (i) establish a fully functional MIS and operational 
capacity within MET and other key agencies and (ii) provide post-delivery technical support and 
follow-up training for the remainder of the TA. The MET has confirmed that it will employ at least 
one full-time officer to operate the MIS and will cover the costs for O&M of the MIS after TA 
completion, including maintaining the servers, internet connections, and salaries. The MET’s 
annual budget allocation will budget and account for these costs. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 
to the Government of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Information 
and Communication Technology for Improving the Management of Hazardous Chemicals, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
